awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Gerald Meyer of the Department of Chemistry at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill is characterizing intermolecular electron transfer reactions for molecules anchored to metal oxide surfaces.  The goal of this research is to exploit self-exchange reactions as a means to transport charge across oxide surfaces for applications in optoelectronic devices, namely for the conversion of solar energy into stored chemical energy or electricity (e.g. dye-sensitized solar cells).  The project lies at the interface of physical organic, inorganic, and materials chemistry, and is therefore well suited to the education of scientists at all levels.  This group is also well-positioned to provide the highest level of education and training for students underrepresented in science.  Outreach activities to grade school students in local and rural North Carolina are also part of the funded project.  

Research has shown that photo-oxidized dye molecules anchored to the sensitized mesoporous nanocrystalline (anatase) TiO2 thin films commonly used for dye-sensitized solar cells undergo self-exchange intermolecular electron transfer reactions (termed hole-hopping) with dynamics and efficiencies that can be tuned at the molecular level.  These findings provide an opportunity to transport charges to desired locations without a loss in Gibbs free energy.  Particular focus wiis being given to address the following fundamental questions: How can molecular structure be tuned to control intermolecular electron transfer?  Is there a correlation between self-exchange reactions in fluid solution and those on oxide surfaces?  Does self-exchange electron transfer between dyes influenced unwanted recombination reactions?  Can self-exchange with molecules that contain two (or more) redox active groups be controlled by the bridge that links them?  A kinetic approach that enables redox equilibria at the adiabatic/non-adiabatic border to be quantified for the first time is being utilized.  The desired electron transfer chemistry is being initiated by pulsed light excitation or with an applied potential and quantified by in situ spectro-electrochemistry, absorption anisotropy, chronoabsorptometry, and transient absorption spectroscopy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our research has shown that photo-oxidized dye molecules anchored to mesoporous nanocrystalline semiconducting (anatase) TiO2 commonly used for dye-sensitized solar cells undergo self-exchange intermolecular electron transfer reactions (termed hole-hopping) with dynamics and efficiencies that can be tuned at the molecular level.  A cartoon for this reactivity is shown in the attached image.  Hole-hopping across insulating mesoporous ZrO2 thin films initiated with a potential step was also quantified with resources provided by this grant.  

The findings from this grant provide an opportunity to transport charges to desired locations without a loss in Gibbs free energy.  Particular focus has been given to: 1. Hole-hopping on metal oxide nanocrystallites; 2. Hole-hopping with competitive charge recombination to the oxidized dye on semiconducting metal oxide nanocrystallites; and 3. Hole-hopping with dye-bridge-donor compounds on semiconducting metal oxide nanocrystallites. An important finding from this grant was that the kinetics for hole-hopping kinetics were correlated with the deleterious recombination reaction between the oxidized dye and an electron injected into a semiconducting oxide.  Indeed,  dyes that underwent rapid hole-hopping showed faster recombination than those that hopped more slowly. This was not an obvious result and the dogma in the field was quite different indicating that the transport of the injected electron controlled the charge recombination rate without regard to the fate of the oxidized dye.

This finding is also relevant to the quest for new materials with tailored interfaces that efficiently harvest solar energy and convert them to redox equivalents that can be stored as a fuel or converted to electrical power.  It provides a new means by which desired reactivity can be optimized and unwanted charge recombination reactions can be minimized. For example, our research has shown that the introduction of sterically bulky groups onto the dye-backbone inhibits hole-hopping and the unwanted charge recombination reaction. Furthermore, it was shown that the kinetics for hole-hopping between dyes with two redox active groups can be tuned by controlling the intramolcular electronic couling between the two redox-acive groups.

A broad impact is assured as this grant has educated a diverse group of scientists to be future professionals and forge interdisciplinary links between molecular coordination chemistry, photoelectrochemistry, photochemistry, and materials science.  The advances that result from the proposed studies have been described at colleges, universities, national meetings and educational workshops, as well as in written research publications and review articles. Our successful outreach program provided hands-on opportunities for grade school students in urban and rural North Carolina to make and test dye sensitized solar cells while learning fundamental aspects of chemistry and photochemistry.  

 


Last Modified: 08/17/2023
Modified by: Gerald J Meyer

Image
  • Cartoon diagram of how an oxidized dye, created by light absorption and excited-state injection, can be translated across an oxide surface by D+/0 self-exchange ?hole-hopping?.
    gerald meyer
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Gerald J Meyer
    Light initiated "Hole-hopping"
